instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3262: What is 820-3262? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS? This is a typo of PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS When you see PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS, assume they meant to type PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello Everyone, I have a water damage macbook that came in with no power. When you connect the charger to the computer without the battery I get a solid orange light but it never turns on. During visual inspection, I was able to find a really corroded capacitor (<CAPACITOR>C7202</CAPACITOR>) near the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (<CHIP>ISL95286</CHIP>)  area. I took some measurements near that area and noticed that the line <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground.  I chased this line down on the schematic and noticed that this line was creared by <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> and this line was shorted as well. I tried injecting some voltage into this line to find the faulty component but I wasn't able to find one. My power PSU will consume 0.98 @ 0.6v. I have attached a image of the damage. what produces this line? Im stuck here

My measurements are the following
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.52v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 15.02v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.40v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0.92v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.10v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
3262 is not a valid number.
Any high side FETs shorted? Check all coils for short to GND too and then check that coil for a short to PPBUS. I bet shorted FET in CPU power supply....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey Duke,  I decided to give this board another try. Hopefully I can get it working. The actual board number is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. As I stated previously, when you connect the charger to the computer without the battery I get a solid orange light but it never turns on. Atm, I have a short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> . What do you mean by high side FETs? Are you referring to the power fets? I check the power FET <CHIP>U8001</CHIP> since it had a cpu line but it seems fine. Not sure where to go with this. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Measure from L7320 to L7130, what is the resistance? Also measure resistance to GND on L7320 and L7130.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 8376"]Measure from L7320 to L7130, what is the resistance? Also measure resistance to GND on L7320 and L7130.[/QUOTE]

The resistance to GND on L7320 is
1) CPU <SIGNAL>VR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> 1.4-6.4 Ohms
2) <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL>  1.4-6.2 Ohms

The resistance to GND on L7130 is
1)<SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> 3.70-14.60 Ohms 
2) <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> 4.7-10.9 Ohms

Also, the resistance to PPBUS from pin 1 of L7320 is  3 Ohms and on pin 2 is 3.6 Ohms. 

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have no idea what you are doing. I am just asking the resistance from one coil to another. It does not matter which side of the coil as the coils are 0 Ohm. So your measurement on L7320 to GND cannot be different on pin 1 and 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Let's just make this simple since this is what goes wrong on all of these boards. Remove <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7320</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7330</CHIP>. If it turns on , 99% chance your CPU is dead. That is what goes wrong with most 3662 with corrosion on the edge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 8430"]Let's just make this simple since this is what goes wrong on all of these boards. Remove <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7320</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7330</CHIP>. If it turns on , 99% chance your CPU is dead. That is what goes wrong with most 3662 with corrosion on the edge.

[/QUOTE]

Thanks Duke & Louis for your advice. I was able to remove the short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> by removing the mosfets <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>. <CHIP>U7320</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7330</CHIP>. The only crappy part is that the computer still doesn't boot up. It just shows me a orange with spinning fans. . I guess my CPU is dead. Right?  I checked the voltage on this line "<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> " and I'm getting 12.52v. 

Thanks,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well the FETs are shorted and the chance this killed the CPU is VERY high. So only continue if you have nothing better to do.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 8491"]Well the FETs are shorted and the chance this killed the CPU is VERY high. So only continue if you have nothing better to do.[/QUOTE]

How can I verify the CPU is dead? I'm pretty sure <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> was causing the problem. It would be nice to give it all I can. Thanks for the help and guidance

Cheers,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3262</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with NO POWER short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_H5_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You can't without changing it, or it must have a hard short on L7320. Experience says 90% chance CPU is dead.
